docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: When it comes to poorly funded pension and retiree health care plans, the main culprit is Congress, not the companies that are providing these benefits.

headline.main: Paying the Price Of Retirees' Health Care

docs.abstract: Adam J Reese letter says that when it comes to poorly funded pension and retirement plans, main culprit is Congress, not companies that are providing benefits (Dec 14 column)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     When it comes to poorly funded pension and retiree health care plans, the main culprit is Congress, not the companies that are providing these benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are a couple of questions that few people seem to be asking about the limited Medicare prescription drug law that goes into effect in 2006: What impact will it have on pharmaceutical companies' programs that offer free drugs to low-income people, including those on Medicare?

headline.main: Two Holes in the Medicare Drug Law

docs.abstract: Fred Brock column on limited Medicare prescription drug law that goes into effect in 2006; discusses its possible impact on pharmaceutical companies' programs that offer free drugs to low-income people, including those on Medicare; questions law's prohibition against beneficiaries' buying private insurance to cover considerable gaps in coverage (M)
docs.snippet: THERE are a couple of questions that few people seem to be asking about the limited Medicare prescription drug law that goes into effect in 2006:     What impact will it have on pharmaceutical companies' programs that offer free drugs to low-income...

docs.lead_paragraph: On the heels of Friday's glum Labor Department report, Americans have a right to be confused. Soaring growth, stocks and consumer confidence have heartened investors. And yet, the country remains mired in a jobless recovery. The reality is that the economy has become more uncertain and anxiety-producing for most of us -- not just over the past three years, but over the past 30. But by fixating on the day-to-day ups and downs, analysts have largely missed the more telling trend: an increasing shift of economic risk from government and corporations onto workers and their families. Signs of this transformation are everywhere: in the laid-off programmer whose stock options are suddenly worthless, in the former welfare mom who can get a job but not health care or day care, in the family forced into bankruptcy by the sickness of a child. But these episodes, while viewed with sympathy, are usually seen in isolation, rather than as parts of a larger problem. This blinkered view stands in the way of both diagnoses of the causes of the new economic insecurity and prescriptions for its cure.

headline.main: Call It the Family Risk Factor

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Jacob S Hacker says there has been increasing shift of economic risk from government and corporations onto workers and their families; says while Americans may be richer than they were, incomes as a whole have grown little for middle class and working poor, and many programs to help poor and middle-class have steadily eroded; calls for new, flexible universal insurance program to protect families against catastrophic expenses and drops in income; says protecting families is necessary and possible, and it offers best hope for reviving constructive role for government in this century; graph (M)
docs.snippet: On the heels of Friday's glum Labor Department report, Americans have a right to be confused. Soaring growth, stocks and consumer confidence have heartened investors. And yet, the country remains mired in a jobless recovery. The reality is that the...

docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE America without illegal immigrants, the people who flip the burgers, clean the toilets, watch the kids and send their children to public schools. Would the grass be greener?

headline.main: The Nation: A New Order; Imagining Life Without Illegal Immigrants

docs.abstract: Pres Bush has reopened national debate about immigration with his proposal to grant temporary visas to undocumented workers; Immigration and Naturalization Service estimates that 15 states account for all but 13 percent of illegal immigrants; most are concentrated in handful of states--California, Texas, New York, Illinois and Florida--leaving many parts of United States relatively untouched by influx; in states where they live, illegal aliens are major source of cheap labor; Pew Hispanic Center estimated in 2001 that unauthorized labor force in US totaled 5.3 million workers; their importance to commerce was illustrated last month in California, when thousands of Latinos stayed home from work to protest repeal of contentious new law that would have allowed illegal immigrants to obtain driver's licenses; photos (M)
docs.snippet: IMAGINE America without illegal immigrants, the people who flip the burgers, clean the toilets, watch the kids and send their children to public schools.     Would the grass be greener?

docs.lead_paragraph: FUNDS that invest in pint-sized stocks achieved supersized returns in 2003. Small-capitalization stock funds, which typically limit their purchases to stocks with market caps of less than $2 billion, trounced funds that buy larger companies.

headline.main: Mutual Funds Report; For Small Caps, '03 May Be Hard to Beat

docs.abstract: Small-capitalization stock funds achieve supersized returns in 2003, trouncing funds that invest in larger companies; many analysts say this should not surprising coming out of bear market, but warn that at this stage of economic recovery, small companies may have used up early advantage that comes from being light on their feet; comments by Boniface Zaino, portfolio manager at Royce Opportunity fund, Michael Hershey, manager of Henlopen fund, and Gerald M Van Horn, co-portfolio manager at Stratton Small-Cap Value fund; photos (M)
docs.snippet: FUNDS that invest in pint-sized stocks achieved supersized returns in 2003.     Small-capitalization stock funds, which typically limit their purchases to stocks with market caps of less than $2 billion, trounced funds that buy larger companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maintenance and operations workers at the Indian Point nuclear power plant were making preparations for a possible strike in the event that negotiations between their union and Entergy Nuclear Northeast, the plant's owner, do not yield a new contract within eight days. While Entergy expressed confidence that a walkout would be averted, a spokesman for Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America said the two sides were far apart on basic issues like salaries and health benefits.

headline.main: Strike by Operations Staff Looms at Indian Pt. Nuclear Plant

docs.abstract: Maintenance and operations workers at Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor in Buchanan, NY, prepare for strike against Entergy Nuclear Northeast, plant's owner, over wages and health benefits; Entergy says that it has plan for operating plant in event of strike and that strike will have no impact on safety (M)
docs.snippet: Maintenance and operations workers at the Indian Point nuclear power plant were making preparations for a possible strike in the event that negotiations between their union and Entergy Nuclear Northeast, the plant's owner, do not yield a new contract...

docs.lead_paragraph: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc., a leading operator of Medicare health plans, said strikes at California supermarkets might lower its earnings this year. Work stoppages over health benefits at Albertson's Inc., the Ralphs Grocery chain of the Kroger Company and the Vons stores of Safeway Inc. may cause PacifiCare to miss goals for increasing membership and trim as much as 19 cents a share from 2004 earnings on a presplit basis, the company said. PacifiCare, which is based in Cypress, Calif., insured about 48,000 United Food and Commercial Workers members who have been striking against the supermarkets since October and provided prescription-drug services to another 200,000. Some employees lost eligibility for coverage because of the strikes, the company said.
docs.abstract: Strikes by employees of several California grocery stores might have adverse effect on earnings of Medicare health plan operator PacifiCare Health Systems Inc; PacifiCare insures 48,000 United Food and Commercial Workers members who have gone on strike since October, and provides drug prescription services to an additional 200,000 striking union workers (S)
docs.snippet: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc., a leading operator of Medicare health plans, said strikes at California supermarkets might lower its earnings this year. Work stoppages over health benefits at Albertson's Inc., the Ralphs Grocery chain of the Kroger...

docs.lead_paragraph: CVS, the drugstore chain, said yesterday that it would not join pharmacy-benefit plans that require consumers to get routine prescriptions exclusively by mail because it sees the practice as reducing competition. CVS said it would not participate in three benefit programs administered by National Medical Health Card Systems, which manages pharmacy benefits for insurers and businesses. The decision excludes plans in which CVS already takes part. Patients want the option of getting 90-day refills at stores, CVS said. It fills more than 10 percent of all prescriptions in the United States.
docs.abstract: Drugstore chain CVS refuses to join three pharmacy-benefit plans, administered by National Medical Health Card Systems, which require patients to obtain routine prescriptions by mail; says mail-order requirement is anti-competitive; mail-order prescriptions grew by 22 percent in US in 2002 (S)
docs.snippet: CVS, the drugstore chain, said yesterday that it would not join pharmacy-benefit plans that require consumers to get routine prescriptions exclusively by mail because it sees the practice as reducing competition.    CVS said it would not participate...

docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the subjects that can cause political and governmental upheaval, an old-fashioned tax revolt is high on the list. Over the years, elected officials from Sacramento to Chicago have faced the wrath of voters angry about high property taxes. This year, in New York, the subject is particularly emotional. A study released in November by a budget watchdog group found that New Yorkers pay more of their income in local taxes than residents of any other state. The news was received like the fuse of a bomb that is moving along closer to detonation each day.

headline.main: County Leaders Tell Albany Need Is Urgent For Tax Relief

docs.abstract: Republican and Democratic county officials from around New York gather in Albany to demand solution to skyrocketing costs of Medicaid, which they say is prime cause of local property tax increases and county budget strains statewide; gather signatures from taxpayers and pledge to battle legislators who ignore their pleas; Thomas R Suozzi of Nassau County leads movement; some criticize Gov George E Pataki for taking credit for new health programs while leaving their financing to counties; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Of all the subjects that can cause political and governmental upheaval, an old-fashioned tax revolt is high on the list. Over the years, elected officials from Sacramento to Chicago have faced the wrath of voters angry about high property taxes.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's immigration reform proposal, unveiled on Wednesday, is a classic guest worker program on the European model. As such, it may be doomed from the start: Europe's guest worker programs created as many problems as they solved, and to this day they remain unpopular. Guest worker programs were widely used in Europe from the 1950's through the 1970's during a period of extreme labor shortages. Most of the several million Turks and Yugoslavs in Germany, for example, are there today because of Germany's substantial guest-worker program of that period. Lesser but substantial numbers of guest workers are also to be found among the Muslim populations of Central and Northern Europe.

headline.main: American Jobs but Not the American Dream

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof David Abraham says Pres Bush's immigration reform proposal may be doomed from the start; says drawbacks of guest worker programs, such as those in Europe, far outweigh their advantages; says experience shows that guest workers rarely want to leave, that they marry locals, have children, encourage their kin and friends to join them in host country, legally or illegally; says, in addition, that Bush has clearly expressed his intention to put employers in charge; calls this sure recipe not only for exploitation of 'guests' but also for depression of American wages generally, especially among immigrants; says Bush's plan values immigrants' talents over their dreams (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush's immigration reform proposal, unveiled on Wednesday, is a classic guest worker program on the European model. As such, it may be doomed from the start: Europe's guest worker programs created as many problems as they solved, and to...
